body.p:
I intended answering your
long and interesting letter, yesterday, but
as I had exhausted all my stock of
news to Stella, I felt myself unable to
write one worthy of my friend “Bene”—
and as mother intends favoring you I
believe with a few lines she wished me
to write yesterday fearing you might have
left Boston ere my letter would have
reached its destination, but I flattered
myself by thinking you would not have
until you had heard from me, me-
-thinks I hear you say how ?— “very
significantly, which would not doubt
mean if translated in plain english
“What presumption”! N ' importe ce m'est
egale— Who would have supposed
the Reverend Isaac Leeser should

ever have become a “meddler”, poor
Mrs Cohen, her ears must have smarted
well, whilst you were writing, you
draw so good a picture of the good
“hold Henglish” lady and family
that you very nearly made me en-
-vious of not being in your place to
have enjoyed not only their acquaintance
but their “toute ensemble”, Did you
see Mrs Joseph in New York? I suppose
not, as you would not have lost so
good an opportunity in lengthening
your letter. We expect Uncle Gershom
on Sunday to spend a day or two with
us as I do not think he will like
leaving his family for a longer time
just before he goes to Europe.

The two Mr Moses are in town, Fred
and Brandon, one from California
the other from China, they have been
here for a week, they say they admire
Philadelphia exceedingly, best entre

nous—I think it is not the city
that excites their admiration as they
have seen nothing of it with the ex-
-ception of Chestnut St, but a
couple of our fair sex, who they are
I leave to your fertile imagination—
We have had quite an excitement
lately that is within the last few
days, about the election of Mayor
Judge Conrad the Whig, and Mr Vaux
the Democractic Candidate, the Whigs
as a matter of course, gained, Father
for the first time I believe voted
for a democrat, but Mr Vaux being
a personal friend of his, could not do
less. Uncle Theodore came on
last Sunday night and stayed till
Tuesday afternoon, he merely came
on with Eugene to see Grandma
who is improving slowly. Have you
seen Mr M. Abecassis who I hear
is in Boston studying law? Your friend

Fanny Levy took tea with us Tuesday
evening, but as I had an engagement
to spend the evening out, she did not enjoy my society if you go
to Niagra I trust you will write me
a faithful description of it, and
ditto for Canada—, but “bevare of the
vomen”, the Canadians in particular
as you know what a fine specimen
we once had in Philadelphia, chaque
à son gaut, what pleases one may not
suit another. There I am half way
down the page and I promised to leave
some space for mother, and I know
you would not like me to break my
word so good bye, trusting this will meet
you in health I remain

As Ma had not an opportunity to add
in this i would not detain my letter
as I know you are all anxiety to
get, she wishes to be kindly remembered
and ? sends her fond love—

wether it should be Reverend or Mr
let me know which you are in the habit of
